awd_titl_txt: RUI: Dense Matter and Gravitational Waves: The Coalescence of Neutron Star Binaries
awd_abstract_narration:
The LIGO Scientific Collaboration and the Virgo Collaborations recently announced the first observation of gravitational waves from merging neutron stars. The first gravitational-wave constraints on neutron-star matter have begun to shine new light on the properties of matter above nuclear density, cross-checking neutron-star measurements in electromagnetic astronomy and informing calculations in nuclear physics. Upgrades to the detectors are in progress, and we are soon to enter an era in which regular observations can used to learn about astrophysical sources. These first constraints will be supplanted by precision measurements that rely on an accurate understanding of how neutron star matter affects gravitational waves. In the proposed work, the CSUF students will explore the impact of dense matter on gravitational waves. This research introduces them to the science community, sparking future participation in gravitational astrophysics, data science, and engineering.

The CSUF group will develop on-the-fly hybrid waveform infrastructure within LIGO software, connecting expensive numerical mergers to long analytic inspirals with desired parameters, yielding waveforms spanning LIGO's entire frequency band and quantifying accuracy requirements. They will determine and work to reduce the systematic errors in gravitational-wave parameter estimation techniques using multiple neutron-star waveform models and simulations. These efforts will connect the information coming from gravitational-wave observations with the broader astrophysical context of dense neutron-star matter and microphysics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neutron stars, the most compact astrophysical objects outside of black holes, are endpoints of stellar evolution and host neutron-rich matter at extremes of density. Their observations provide a unique laboratory for dense matter, and a testing ground for the theoretical predictions of nuclear physics.

This project funded work to use the new field of gravitational-wave astronomy to learn about the dense matter physics of neutron stars. This work has primarily taken place in the LIGO Scientific Collaboration; PI Jocelyn Read was co-lead of the LIGO/Virgo Extreme Matter team throughout the funded period. This work funded LIGO/Virgo publications exploring methods of using the first neutron star merger observation of LIGO and Virgo in 2017 to directly compare candidate models for neutron-star matter. New understanding of dense matter based on observing the first neutron-star merger was then used by LIGO and Virgo interpret additional merger observations; in particular, the CSUF group contributed to matter-related work for the second double neutron star in 2019, a mystery object seemingly too heavy to be a neutron star in 2019, and two neutron-star/black-hole mergers observed in 2020. 

This project also funded Read and visiting student Rossella Gamba to work with colleague Leslie Wade to quantify the impact of uncertainties in the neutron-star crust on statements made by the LIGO and Virgo collaboration, determining that it gave an additional source of systematic uncertainty of about 0.5 km for statements about the neutron-star radius.  No impact was found on measurements of the tidal observable of gravitational waves.

Read's group has also contributed to investigations of next-generation detector design, and the impact of design choices on an instrument's ability to inform dense matter physics. 

This award has directly supported training and mentorship in science and technology for undergraduate and masters students at CSUF, who are participating in cutting-edge gravitational-wave science while also building technical skills in data science that enable multiple pathways to career success.

Read also gave 29 invited talks in the funded period, incluing pedagogical presentations for scientists in other fields and undergraduate-focused institutions. She contributed to the organization of nine conferences and workshops, and was interviewed for eight magazine articles including for Wired, Scientific American, Nature News, and Quanta.
